Albany, OR 6/23/2012 1 photo I end up here more often than I would like, especially considering it's in Portland and Portland has a TON of restaurants. The food is fine. Maybe a bit pricey for fast food, but it's pretty good fast food so that's alright. They've got pretty good shakes too. Service wise, I've always been pretty impressed. The one time a year that I go up and stay in Portland for a while is with FIRST Robotics, a robotics competition that has a regional event in Portland. As such, when I go to Portland, there is also a hoard of other people in the same situation as myself. Two of the three times I went into the Burgerville in that week, it was completely filled with high-schoolers (and mentors!). And even then, the people working the counter remained friendly. Both years in which we've hit this Burgerville, they messed up my friend's order of fries... But he just goes up and mentions it and they give him another order of fries for free. It's hard to complain when you get free stuff.
However, the best thing about this location is fairly new. Their soda machines. MY GOD THEIR SODA MACHINES. Basically you can have any soda that you want, in any flavor that you want (assuming what you want is under the 'Coke' label). There are over 100 flavors available. I've heard tell that most of them don't actually taste that good (something to do with how the sodas are mixed up), but I didn't notice because I was drinking diabetes in liquid form (as in, all of the flavors I could fit in one cup). One of my friends proclaimed that he wanted to marry the soda machine, and I can't really blame him. Really the main reason I wrote this review was to talk about the AWESOME SODA MACHINE. I am easily amused.

Cincinnati, OH 5/13/2012 1 Check-in Here Sometimes when visiting a new city, one does not always have the luxury of having the time to find that hole in the wall, out of the way restaurant that they saw on such and such travel show special. When that time comes, the answer is almost always to settle for something fast, and something cheap. In comes Burgerville!
Before my trip to the Northwest, I had never actually seen a Burgerville before, due to the fact that they are a regional chain. However, after walking in, it felt very much like any other fast food joint one would find themselves in. The tables were a little dirty, the smell of fries was in the air, and the teenagers working there seemed less than interested in what was going on around them.
Even so, the service turned out to be better than expected, and my food was presented to me promptly. Once I returned to my hotel room, I was happy to find that it was still hot, and quite tasty. Was it anything special? No. Would I return to a Burgerville again in the future? Most definitely yes. For the price, you are going to experience a better quality burger here than you would at say McDonalds, or Burger King.

Napa, CA 8/23/2011 Burgerville USA sounds like a cheesy greasy fast food joint. One expects something so homespun that yesterday's grease is on today's burger. Instead, it is MARVELOUS! While In-N-Out is the quintessential California chain, Burgerville is Pacific Northwestern. They use local products like blueberries and hazelnuts.
For a local, organic fast food chain it's unpretentious. One could easily imagine Guy Fieri dropping by to taste the burgers&sweet potato fries. It's that kind of place. Here in the Bay Area, being eco-friendly tends to the preachy... but Burgerville does it unobtrusively.
I ordered the Harvest Burger, thinking it had the latest of the summer harvest. Turns out it was the veggie burger--it was EXCELLENT! The sweet potato fries and the shakes are delicious.
Chez Gourmet however sells the Burgerville "Oregon Harvest" burgers online and Whole Foods. http://www.chezgourmet.b… Yes,these can be relished here in California!
Burgerville takes "do you want fries with that?" to a whole new level! Dig in!

Portland, OR 8/7/2011 1 Check-in Here I know, I know. Burgerville is awesome for being environmentally friendly and locally based. For goodness sakes, they have three different trash baskets to separate between food, paper, and other stuff. There is even a warning label on the straw stating not to put it in a hot beverage because it is made out of corn and it will melt. I get it. That is why the price is little bit on the higher end. But I get it. It's awesome. And the burgers are delicious.
But the reason why I am giving 4 stars is this. It may have been my own ignorance but I was still little bit disappointed by it.
As you Burgerville fans may know, this month is its 50th anniversary! Yay!~ Soooo, my family and I went to yesterday to celebrate its 50th birthday along with some very special deals that Burgerville was offering. Originial hamburger = $.89. OG Cheeseburger = $.99. Etc. All excited, I ordered the OG hamburger. I wasn't quite sure what to expect but I was expecting a hamburger.
Before I go on, let me just confirm that I'm not delusional. A hamburger is made with two buns, lettuce, tomatoes, beef patty(ies), mayo, and maybe mustard and pickles. Right? Or am I crazy?
Anyways, when I got my order I had to hold my tongue from saying very mean and nasty things in front of my young nephews and nieces.
A slice of beef patty that was, I swear to All Mighty, almost thin as a Time Magazine with a drop of mustard that were sandwiched between two buns. Damn. Is that what they served 50 years ago? Maybe that's why obesity in US was so low.
So like I've said, maybe I was expecting too much from this birthday party. Was I even invited?

Portland, OR 6/27/2011 This is a review for a fast food joint, and as far as fast food joints go, this really is as good as it gets.
I grew up in the south, so I got a LOT of McDonald's, a lot of Burger King, etc. The closest place that I grew up with that comes in comparison to Burgerville is a Steak n' Shake, which is a sit-down diner. Mostly the comparison comes in with the Milk-shakes, for those who are familiar with Steak n' Shake. Get the Fresh fruit milk-shakes, not the standard flavor in a can milk-shakes... but that's the same as it was for Steak n' Shake.
As far as comparison to other Burgers in the area, far more flavorful than Dick's restaurant, burger for burger, and unspeakably better than Red Robin. (it comes without all the kids parties too.)
Is this a gourmet burger? No, not unless you're a fast food gourmet. Its fresh, local ingredients (that taste fresh!) in a very tasty combination.
Some words of warning. You want to buy a Tilimook Cheeseburger or above on the menu. The cheep burgers aren't any better than McDonald's. Ewy. DON"T get the regular style milk-shakes. Its flavor in a can, and you'd be missing out on the fresh fruit amazingness. Also, if its the right time of year for Rosemary fries, GET THEM. or the Fried mushroom Wedges. Yum.
Also, this location prints your calories for you. I, for one, appreciate this. However, it is fast food, so you're not going to be getting low-calorie meals. Sure, its no Burger King, but you can easily get a full day's calories in one sitting.
Also, you can go through the drive through on your bike, a total bonus. Makes you feel less guilty about those delicious calories you're consuming.

Where was the Tillamook cheese? We always prepare our burgers at home with a thick slice of Tillamook cheese, but this was a thin slice that doesn't do justice to a cheeseburger, again lacking flavor. The slices of tomato were thin as well, and didn't have the flavorful burst of, say, tomatoes in a In-N-Out burger. The shakes were fine, nothing special. Are people so happy about the 'mission' of local/sustainable that they overlook that this is just another warming tray fast food restaurant?
To sum it up? If I bought a house in Burgerville, I'd be upside down on my mortgage about now.

Portland, OR 6/2/2009 This Burgerville location is very similar to all of the others. Good food (for fast food), mostly locally sourced and sustainable ingredients, high quality meats, and tasty seasonal offerings make this local chain a total winner in my drive-thru book.
This particular location is a bit of an oasis in an otherwise dead zone for food. In the netherworld between the convention center, the rose garden, and the office parks between that district and lloyd, there's not much in the way of food. Denny's, Red Robin, Sbux, and Burgerville. So this has become an emergency stop when I am needing a quick meal pre- or post-event, or one of those other random times when you just need some grub, and fast.
The lines at this place can get horrendous when Blazer games or similar events are going on at the nearby centers. The staff does a good job of handling the crush of people, but I've still had to wait quite some time for my food due simply to the sheer volume of people. At other times, the place is a ghost town. I can get in, get food, and get out in a flash.
The food at this Burgerville beats the hell out of the food at the Montavilla location. The burgers I get are not crushed and battered, the breakfast sandwiches are warm all the way through, and, well, hey... it's chain fast food. What more description do you need?
It does the job it's supposed to do, and it does it with much more style than the major fast food chains. For that, 4-stars.
Oh, and their morning coffee is not half bad (again, for fast food).

Portland, OR 7/24/2007 Burgerville is the Four Seasons of fast food.
All Northwest ingredients, cooked to order, and tasty! Dine in for the diner vibe or drive through so you can listen to your own music (they usually have a juke box inside).
Burgerville offers a variety of seasonal favorites: sweet potato fries, Walla Walla onion rings, chocolate-hazelnut or blackberry milkshakes (damn, all of their milkshakes are SO GOOD), strawberry shortcake, just to name a few.
I always get the Tillamook Peppered Bacon cheeseburger basket. Comes with fries and a drink for under $8. If you don't want red meat, try the Halibut Fish and Chips or Chicken Strips and Fries. They also have salads, for you anti-flesh fans.

King, WA 11/15/2010 2 photos 1 Check-in Here If it looks like a duck and quacks like a duck....it's a duck, right?
Well this place may look like a fast food restaurant, but it's definitely not the typical McDonalds, Burger King, etc. I've seen this place many times on my trips to Portland, and I finally decided to check it out and I'm so glad I did.
Yes, the food is a little on the expensive side, but with a motto like "Fresh, Local, Sustainable," I don't mind playing the extra buck for a better quality meal. I ordered the Rosemary chicken sandwich while my boyfriend ordered the turkey club. I was surprised by the product! It definitely wasn't fine dining, but our food could have easily passed for a sit-down lunch at a little diner or restaurant. My rosemary chicken was tender, flavorful, and simply done - not overly dressed. (You can hardly ever go wrong with rosemary + chicken) The turkey club must have been devoured in seconds, so I'm guessing it was very enjoyable too. Portland, OR 8/5/2009 This is civilized fast food. It's as simple as that. It's not a gourmet steak: that's not why we're here, but for fast food, it's pretty damn good. Plus, Burgerville proves that you can do fast food in a more local, sustainable way -- it's not that the other chains can't do the same... it's that they choose not to.
Plus, at this location, I've generally found polite and pleasant people waiting to take your order and answer questions, suggesting things that you might like without sounding like salesmen. Service is quick and the place is clean.
I just noticed that even the receipts are pretty cool, showing the nutritional stats for your order (although this would have been nice to see in more plain view prior to ordering). What impresses me the most is how they deal with waste: even their straws are corn-based and can be composted. In our meal last night, NOTHING went into the "landfill" can -- it was all compostable. Very impressed.
Yeah, it's a couple of bucks more expensive than McWhatever, but it's worth every penny. It's local, it's run the right way, and it's damned good. While you're there -- treat yourself to a milkshake with whatever fruit is in season. They're always, always good.
